items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message: River levels have receded, however Derwent Water remains high but steadily receding following recent heavy rainfall.  Derwent Water remains high affecting low lying areas bordering the shores of Derwent Water.  Areas most at risk are the Upper Derwent from Seathwaite to Derwent Water. We continue to monitor levels closely and are clearing debris from weed screens in the area. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated tomorrow morning 12/10/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal River Avon at Bristol, Pill and Shirehampton

floodArea.county: City of Bristol, North Somerset, South Gloucestershire

items.message: Flood alert issued for this evening 11/10/22 as a result of high spring tides. Forecast high water is at 21:15 on Tuesday 11/10/22 with a level of 7.40 mAOD and force 2 south easterly wind. All times are local and refer to the high water time at Avonmouth.  Flooding to roads and farmland is possible at this time, however conditions may apply up to one hour either side of the high tide.  We expect flooding to affect the tidal River Avon from Sea Mills to Conham in Bristol and between the Avonmouth Bridge and Shirehampton Park including Pill and Shirehampton. We are closely monitoring the situation and our incident response staff are closing flood gates and checking defences. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and be careful along promenades, coastal footpaths and roads. This message will be updated by 11.00 on Wednesday 12/10/22.

items.description: The Essex coast from St Peters Flat to and including Shoeburyness and the Crouch and Roach estuaries

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Crouch, River Roach, North Sea

items.message: Levels are now below the flood risk thresholds.  The forecast is for reduced flood risk from high tides.  There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away.  Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.  We will continue to monitor levels closely.
